Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type2: In-Situ, Wireless, Energy-Harvesting Soil Moisture/Nutrient Sensors for Managing Agricultural Resources & Environmental Impact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will address Cyber-Enabled Nutrient Management for Sustainable Agriculture through precise spatial/temporal control of agricultural inputs for optimized resource utilization and minimized environmental impact. There is a critical need for the development of cyber technologies in production agriculture that allow automated collection of real-time spatial soil and crop data while advancing a deeper understanding of the fertilizer inputs and nitrogen (N) cycling. This project aims to develop: (1) In-situ, accurate, self-calibrating, self-localizing soil sensors for monitoring soil properties such as soil moisture and nitrates, (2) Small antenna technologies for underground communication so the sensors do not interfere with agricultural operations, (3) Effective techniques for broadband energy-harvesting from vibrational sources (eg., thunder and farming operations); (4) Modeling and analysis methods for understanding the underlying nitrogen cycling at high spatial/temporal resolutions, and information management and decision-making tools for precise agricultural control.

Managing the nitrogen Cycle is one of the grand challenges identified by the National Academies. Nitrogen fertilizers from farm fields are major source of water quality impairment and the leading contributor to hypoxia. The project is a step towards developing deeper understanding of agricultural N cycling process while developing precise controls over N fertilizer inputs that are key to sustainable agriculture. To enhance educational and workforce development efforts, the PIs will contribute to a graduate minor in Sustainable Agriculture by introducing new curriculum material on Bio-Chemical Sensors. PhD students of the funded research will enroll in the Sustainable Agriculture minor, thus developing a new generation of workforce trained in the aspects of cybersystems, agroecosystems, environmental monitoring, and sustainable cultivation. To achieve wider awareness and reception, PIs will work closely with industry and government organizations in the agricultural sector, several of whom have expressed interest through supporting letters.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported, in parts, the following works:

1. Design of in-situ soil moisture and salinity sensor, along with its metamaterials based small flat antenna that can be buried underground, and it duals as the sensing probe (Phd work of Gunjan Pandey; now with Skyworks)

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6746077

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8424404

2. Design of microfluidic sensor for in-situ soil nutrient sensing using electrophoretic separation of ions and an integrated automated soil solution extraction unit (PhD work of Zhen Xu; now with Bright Garden Robotics)

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7929360

3. Design of optical sensor for plant-emitted volatile organic compound sensing (PhD work of Shawana Tabassum, continuing as Postdoc within the group)

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8025380

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8010768

https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-26-5-6331

4. Model calibration algorithms for modeling agricultural production system capturing soil water dynamics, nutrient cycling, and plant growth dynamics (PhD work of Anupam Bhar; expected to defend in 2020; continuing as a researcher at Center for Survey Statistics and Methodology, here at ISU)

https://elibrary.asabe.org/abstract.asp?aid=49230

https://elibrary.asabe.org/abstract.asp?aid=50623

https://elibrary.asabe.org/abstract.asp?aid=50776

5. Study of nitrogen mineralization (PhD work of Navreet Mahal; now Professor at South Dakota State University)

https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fevo.2019.00059/full

https://dl.sciencesocieties.org/publications/sssaj/abstracts/82/5/1270

6. Initial work on soil-sensor network for precision agriculture (PostDoc work of Jing Hunag; joined NXP after completing, now with AMD)

https://elibrary.asabe.org/abstract.asp?aid=24793&t=2&redir=&redirType=

Design of Physical/MAC/Network layers for energy-efficient soil-sensor wake-up synchronization, scheduling, and routing; Soil-sensor localization using received-signal-strength or time-of-arrival measurements (PhD work of Herman Sahota; joined IBM after graduating, now with Anthem.ai)

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/wcm.1229

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7475882

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6819626

7. Vibration energy harvesting using a piezoelectric transducer, with bistable mode of operation for broadband application, along with a self-actuated feedback mechanism for lowering the amplitude required for bistable operation (Phd work of Kanishka Singh; joined NextEra Energy after graduating, now part of his own Start-up MCARTech)

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7017555

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8434254

NOTE: The links to the most up-to-date journal or conference articles are provided above as references to the works completed.

The primary contributing PhD students/postdoc (7 PhDs and 1 Postdoc) have also been named; they have all found excellent placements and contributing there. One of them is a faculty (Navreet), another has setup his own start-up (Kanishka), two are continuing as researchers on-campus (Shawana and Anupam), and 4 others are placed in various industries: RF/Analog design (Gunjan), Data-Analytics and Machine-learning (Herman), Automation (Zhen), and Digital VLSI Verification (Jing).

Two patents have been awarded (soil moisture and salinity sensing; vibration energy harvesting); two others are pending (optical gas sensing; dual-modality biomarker detection)

http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=10073074.PN.&OS=PN/10073074&RS=PN/10073074

http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-adv.htm&r=1&p=1&f=G&l=50&d=PTXT&S1=10224835&OS=10224835&RS=10224835
